resources.text: Now let's see that generic printer, finally. Check this sample for the syntax:
resources.code:
public class Printer<T> {
    
    private T object;
    
    public Printer(T object) {
         this.object = object;
    }
    
    public void print() {
         System.out.println(object.toString());
    }

    public T getPrintObject() {
         return object;
    }
}
resources.text: The key is that T, between the <> symbols. That is going to define a type parameter, and this type can later be used inside the class declaration. For example it's used as
resources.list:
• a member.
  • a parameter (in the constructor).
  • a return value (in the getter method).
resources.boxed: Anything that can be used as a normal identifier can also be used a type parameter name. However, convention is that single, capital letters are used! For some reason, T and E is especially popular.
resources.text: This class can then be constructed like this:
resources.code:
//A printer for strings
Printer<String> p1 = new Printer<>("text");
//A printer for doubles
Printer<Double> p2 = new Printer<>(3.14);
//Printer for objects, will generate warnings
Printer p3 = new Printer(new Object());
//Proper way for object printer
Printer<Object> p4 = new Printer<>(new Object());
resources.text: Not much new here, we've seen how to instantiate generic classes like collections before. Except maybe the 3. statement, which also works, despite the lack of a type argument.
resources.boxed:
The reason why no type parameters are needed is backwards compatibility. Before generics, collections were written for Object, like the Printer class in the previous chapter. When generics were introduced, collections were rewritten.

By allowing declarations without type parameters, old code that uses non-generic collections will still compile.
resources.text: This code is now type safe, if we try to do some invalid casting, we will get an error at compile time.
resources.code:
//A printer for strings
Printer<String> p1 = new Printer<>("text");
//compile time ERROR!!!
int number = p1.getPrintObject();
//also compile time ERROR!!!
int number = (int)p1.getPrintObject();
resources.text: Any number of type parameters is allowed. This shouldn't come as a surprise, since we've seen such classes before, like a HashMap. Here is an example, and the syntax to declare them:
resources.code:
public class Pair<S, T> {

    private S s;
    private T t;
    
    public Pair(S s, T t) {
         this.t = t;
         this.s = s;
    }
    
    //other methods here...
}
resources.text: Declaring generic methods is also allowed. This is because of classes that can't be instantiated, and have static methods don't miss out on the generic fun (typically used for utility classes).
resources.code:
public abstract class Utility {

    public static <T> void print(T object) {
         System.out.println(object.toString());
    }
    
}
resources.text:
Note that the method type parameters must be given between the modifiers and the return value. Then, these types can be used as the return value or parameters of the method (but only for this method).

You use such a method just like any traditional one:
Interfaces can also be generic. This is not surprising, as interfaces are just fully abstract classes, so it makes sense for interfaces to also support generics. We've seen multiple examples:
resources.list:
• java.lang.Comparable: The type parameter is the object type that will be compared.
  • java.util.concurrent.Callable: The type parameter is the return value of the process.
  • All interfaces in the collections framework (List, Map, Set, ...)
resources.advanced: Primitives are not allowed as generic arguments (discussed this already in the data structures course). This isn't a problem however, because the wrapper classes and autoboxing, primitives can also be used seamlessly. Just make sure you use the wrapper classes when instantiating generic classes.
